Which Crypto Exchanges Do Not Report to the IRS?      Introduction In 2026, U.S. crypto taxation is more structured as the IRS expands reporting and enforcement, even for altcoins like $SOL  and $XRP . While some exchanges share user data with tax authorities, others do not. Understanding this difference is essential for U.S. taxpayers.     Which exchanges do not report? Decentralized exchanges and foreign centralized exchanges that do not serve U.S. residents generally do not report to the IRS. They do not issue tax forms, but tax obligations still apply.     Why DEXs do not report DEXs operate via smart contracts without user accounts or identity checks. Platforms like Uniswap and PancakeSwap collect no personal data, though all transactions are visible on public blockchains.     Non-U.S. centralized exchanges Platforms such as Bitget and OSL comply with local regulations, not U.S. tax law. Users are responsible for self-reporting.     Peer-to-peer platforms Usually non-custodial and non-reporting, though some apply limited identity checks.  Does non-reporting remove tax duties? No. U.S. taxpayers must report worldwide crypto income and gains. The IRS uses blockchain analytics to track activity.     How crypto is taxed Crypto is treated as property. Capital gains apply to sales or swaps, while income tax applies to mining, staking, and rewards.      Overall Non-reporting exchanges reduce data sharing, not taxes owed. Compliance depends on accurate self-reporting.      FAQ Non-reporting does not remove legal risk. DEX activity is traceable on chain. Bitget and DEXs do not issue IRS forms. Using non-reporting platforms does not reduce taxes.   https://www.bitget.com/academy/which-crypto-exchanges-do-not-report-to-irs    #MacroInsights

Understanding $SOL  -to-USD Exchange Rates: A 2026 Guide to Fees and Conversion Methods.  INTRODUCTION Converting Peruvian Soles (PEN) to US Dollars (USD) in 2026 depends largely on how the exchange is made. Cash withdrawals, card payments, and online transfers all apply different fees and exchange rate markups, which can noticeably reduce the final amount received, especially for larger transactions.   Why do PEN/USD rates differ by method? Banks, card issuers, ATM operators, and transfer platforms each use their own pricing models. These include FX markups, fixed service fees, foreign transaction charges, and Dynamic Currency Conversion (DCC), which often increases costs when accepted.  How much can rates vary? â€¢ Online transfers and crypto platforms: ~0.5â€“1.5% above mid-market â€¢ Fee-free card payments: ~1â€“2% â€¢ Cards with FX fees: ~2â€“4% â€¢ ATM withdrawals: ~3â€“8% â€¢ Airport exchanges: 10% or more As of January 2026, the mid-market rate is about 1 PEN = 0.298 USD, though actual payouts are usually lower after fees.  Why are ATMs more expensive? ATM withdrawals combine bank FX fees, operator charges, and hidden rate markups. Accepting DCC can add an extra 3â€“8% to the cost.  Which option is most efficient? Fintech and crypto platforms like Wise, Revolut, and Bitget typically offer the best rates. Cards are convenient but vary by issuer, while cash and airport exchanges are the least cost-effective.  Conclusion Online transfers consistently provide the best value for PEN/USD conversions. Cards sit in the middle, while ATMs and airport desks remain the most expensive. Choosing the right method can significantly reduce long-term conversion losses.  FAQ (Quick Answers)  â€¢ Current rate: ~0.298 USD per PEN â€¢ Bank rates worse than Google?
